But the burden on industry is another thing, and if we are to legislate in the way of the relief of rates we ought to legislate in such a way as to relieve the pressure of the burden on the small people—the resident occupiers, the cottagers, the small shopkeepers, and other people of the kind who do feel the burden of the rates. I agree that even here there is a great difference between the apparent and immediate incidence and the ultimate incidence of the rate. It is perfectly clear that a Bond-street shopkeeper who pays a very high rent and a very high rate does not pay that rent and rate himself. He would not take a shop in Bond-street unless he knew that he would there find a class of customer to deal with him at prices which cover the high cost of the rent and the rates of his house. therefore in talking of these things you never can put your finger exactly on the spot where the burden ceases or on the man who pays it. 148 We are all of us trying to pass our burdens on to our neighbours; some succeed, and some fail; but he would be a hold man who could say that he could point to the first bearer who had succeeded in passing it on. When we talk of the great increase of the rates we must bear in mind that that increase has been much more urban than rural. All these questions are of the greatest difficulty and the greatest complexity, and if the Government intend to deal with them next session, I think they will need to have a session equal in duration to that of last year and consider no other business at all, for the questions raised will touch the Poor-law and go to the root of the whole of our social life. It will not be enough to give time only; it will be necessary to give a great deal of knowledge and thought also to the matter.
I have some sympathy with the noble Earl who spoke from the Cross Benches (Lord Cromer) who said we were apt to rush cheerfully into expenditure before we knew where we should find the money to meet it, and I was struck with what was said by the noble Earl who introduced this debate, by the noble Lord who represents the county councils, and by others. They spoke with censure of Parliament passing Bills involving great additional burdens on the rates without considering where the money was to come from. But, my Lords, I have recently seen these various Bills go through—Bills for police superannuation on a higher scale, for a police weekly day of rest, and all that, one of them moved, I think, from the opposite Benches and passed without a word; and I venture to say that although your Lordships have no control over finance, still you have control over legislation, and I have not heard a word of objection from the other side when these Bills putting burdens on the rates have been brought in, or any Motion that the Bill be read this day six months.
: I opposed as strongly as I could the Police (Weekly Rest-Day) Bill on behalf of a borough.

: The noble Lord is perfectly right, but I am afraid he met with no response. As I say, the greatest burden thrown on the rates in the last few years was the burden imposed by the Education Act of 1902. The noble Lord and his friends rushed joyfully into that expenditure, and when they went down to their
149 counties they were equally delighted to give the benefit of a large public expenditure to their friends of the Voluntary schools. You must not, therefore, complain so much now when you have been parties to the policy. I dare say some of you in your hearts do not like this policy of liberal expenditure for public objects, but the misfortune is that at the present day you dare not say openly that you dislike it. These things are popular, and it is very difficult to get any politician, on whatever side of the House he may be, to take up a strong opposition to a thing which he believes is popular. You will offend the constitutents of your relatives or your friends whom you want to get into the other House, and so you all run away. You say, "Let us associate ourselves together and not raise our voices in opposition to this expenditure." One or two noble Lords do, but they cry in the wilderness.
We are going to end this debate with a Motion for Papers which I suppose will be granted. May I say I do not think these Papers will be of any use to us? I can quite understand carefully-prepared tables of finance being of use, even from other countries, but the finance of other countries is so different that unless you go into it more deeply then any Parliamentary Paper will do you will get nothing of great profit. In Germany the local authorities get a share of the Income Tax. Whatever Income Tax is put on by the central Government, so many pennies in the pound are added, up to a certain point, for local expenditure. In America you will find that practically the whole cost of education is borne locally. In Germany, again, the bulk of the cost of elementary education is born locally. All these things are so different and require so much knowledge that really you ought to get a Royal Commission of the most dispassionate, statistically-minded, and well-informed people before you could get a Report which would be of much use. Probably the newspapers would do it better than any Government, because the newspapers pitch into one another. If one newspaper misrepresents the facts on one side, the other side will show it up; and I think from the public Press you might elaborate something useful out of the criticisms passed week by week. But I do not think this Return will do a bit of good. Still, you can turn the Government statisticians on and they will give you what you want.
: They have not said that they were going to give it.

: I thought they were preparing tables. I am very glad to hear they are not going to give it; there will be fewer Blue-books thrown at our heads: This question is so intricate and difficult and involves so many Second Reading speeches, every Member of the House taking up the point in which he is interested, that I do not think we are making any material progress. We can only take one small part of the question at a time usefully and direct our attention to some particular detail. To ramble over the whole field and talk of the grievances of London people and the grievances of agricultural people is so wide and so wild that I do not think we get any great advantage.

: My Lords, the noble Lord who has just sat down began his speech by commenting on the wideness of the subject we have before us, and be gave your Lordships at the end of his speech some very sound advice as to talking on one part of the subject at a time only. I am not quite sure whether his speech tended to narrow the discussion or not.
: I merely followed the several speakers and criticised them.

: I was going to say that there has been no speech in the debate which dealt with so wide a variety of subjects or more widened the area of discussion than the speech of the noble Lord who has just sat down. I would like, before I go further, to associate myself with the compliment paid to the noble Earl who introduced this subject. I think any one who listened to his speech must have realised that, so far as regards the part he took up, he had thoroughly studied it and learnt his case. It seemed to me to be an extremely cogent case on the point with which he chiefly dealt.
No one knows better than I do how very large and complicated a subject this is. Before I sit down I shall touch on one aspect of it and venture to hope that I shall make at least one practical suggestion. But, as I say, it is a very complicated subject, and, as the noble Lord who just sat down said, it is a subject which cannot be dealt with within the compass of one
151 speech. But, my Lords, it is a really important. Subject, and one that is worth consideration. I believe there is nothing which would be more fraught with benefit to the people of this country than that it should he studied, and studied, so far as it is possible to study this question, in an impartial spirit. With one remark of the noble Lord I cordially agree—namely, that the man who is to be mainly considered is the small man who lives in a house in a populous area. If you increase the burden upon inhabited houses by the value of the house you certainly will prejudice the poor man at the expense of the richer one.
But if you are going to relieve the humbler man, do get rid of the system of compounding. Do let the poor man know what he is paying. At the present time, by the operation of the system of compounding, he thinks that everything which he pays to the landlord is rent, and is put into the landlord's pocket. He sees the rent going up, and he thinks the landlord is selfish and grasping, and is putting a burden upon him for the benefit of himself. If there is one reform in this country more needed than another it is that, even if the rates are paid through the landlord, the sum should be gathered from the tenant in such a way as to show the tenant what he is paying for rent and what he is paying by way of rates for the services by which he is benefited. That is the one thing which I think everybody who has studied this question, whether from the imperial, local, practical, or social point of view, is absolutely agreed upon. I do hope that point will not be lost sight of if we are going into the reform of local burdens of taxation.
In the course of this discussion grievances of various kinds have been touched upon. The noble Lord, Lord Clinton, was not quite accurate, I think, in saving that rating is all upon real property. I think I am right when I say that personal property includes leaseholds. Now leaseholds are rated, and, therefore, the real distinction in this matter is not between real and personal property, but between property which is movable and property which is immovable —that is practically, as we know it, property which is rateable and property which is not rateable.
There are also complaints from ratepayers in general that they are too much 152 burdened, and that too much is put upon them in proportion to those who own this non-rateable property. There are complaints also among special classes of ratepayers in the same district. There are complaints and discussions between urban ratepayers and country ratepayers, and there is also the question, which was touched upon in the course of this debate, as to the grievance between urban ratepayers and the owners of urban lands. But I am not going to enter into these topics. They are a fertile source of discussion, but I venture to think that too little has been made by some of the speakers of the distinction between various kinds of rates. One noble Lord behind me spoke of an average rate of so much, but there is nothing more fallacious than averages in this matter. You have to look at what makes up the rate. If you say that the average of country rates and urban rates is so much in the pound, it is a most misleading and fallacious statement, because in the larger sum there are a great number of services rendered and paid for which are not done for the man in the rural area. Let me give two instances which are at the extremes as between what are called national and onerous on the one side, and local and beneficial on the other. No one can say that a rate for the supply of water, or of drainage, is anything but a payment for a service rendered. On the other hand, a poor rate, is, perhaps, in its essence absolutely onerous, and though the effect of it and the amount of it are largely influenced by local policy, one can hardly say that either this or the payment for education is other than really a national service and the carrying out of national policy. You cannot, however, lay down a definite rule for all cases and say, "This service is national, that is local, this is onerous, that is beneficial." The two run into one another in such a way that you cannot form a catalogue or list of them and put on one side those which are national and those which are local. But all that is almost commonplace.
The point I want to pass to is, What is the remedy for the admittedly unfair circumstances under which we are living? May I venture to say with what pleasure I heard the announcement of the noble Earl the Leader of the House, that the Government really mean to take up this question. I am afraid I have not much influence, but to those who have I venture
153 to say that if those who are in power and authority in the two Parties could establish and lay down some general principle we should not have this matter discussed as a contest between town and country, between the owner of personal property and the owner of real property, between people in different parts of the country. I would like to see some sound principle laid down which would be of practically universal application. An important point, to which I do not think sufficient attention has been paid in the past, is the way in which the national contribution is to be given to the local administration of services. Everybody admits that it must be increased. But the danger is that, if those who are responsible for local administration find that the more they expend the greater will be the national assistance they will receive, a direct premium will be placed upon extravagance. That must be avoided. Personally I do not like the system of assigned revenues. I do not think it fair to the poorer localities. As to the suggestion made by one noble Lord that the Government should take over more services I do not think that can go much further than it has gone. For my part I would rather see the services efficiently conducted locally. It is much better for the locality, and infinitely more likely to tend to making ways and means meet each other, and to local needs being supplied. On account of the system under which the local revenue is raised, it is unfair to one class of property, and. I venture to say you cannot have anything in the nature of local Income Tax or anything of that kind. You must get the assistance out of the Imperial Exchequer.
My Lords, the problem is how to be fair to the locality without risk of undue extravagance at the expense of the National Exchequer. It seems to me that the only way in which you can do it is to find some way of estimating what is the necessary minimum cost of any one of these services, which are partly national and partly local, in a given locality. This is no new point. This was, I frankly say, a fad of my own, and if any one will pay me the compliment of looking at the separate recommendations which I put into the Local Taxation Commission volume he will see there in full how it is worked out. Briefly the theory is this, that the contribution which is to be given from the central authority must have considerable relation to the necessary 154 cost of the service in question. This applies whether it is poor rate, or education, or such a matter as police; and it ought also so to be given as to afford a lever to the local authorities for improving local administration, both in efficiency and in economy. The only way that I can see of effecting this is by giving block grants, not by means of assigned revenue or by a payment once for all; but by a payment set for a period of years, to be revised according to changed circumstances and to have distinct relation to the ability of the locality to bear the burden. It may be difficult to test what is the ability of an individual ratepayer, but the ability of a locality is very easily ascertained by taking together the amount of the valuation and the population. You will find, if you look into it, that this system has this curious result, that it, gives more to the poorer localities, whether they are poor because they are densely populated localities or whether they are poor on account of the sparseness of their population and the low valuation. What I suggest is that it should be in all cases found out, as can easily be done, what is the average minimum expenditure necessary in any district for the due discharge of these services. When you have found out what is the certain minimum expenditure necessary in any district and the ability of the district to hear the burden, then a. test of administration can be applied by seeing whether the service very much exceeds the average cost or not. When it exceeds the average cost there should be a less contribution from the central authority in so far as that excess over the average cost was due to maladministration.
It is, as I have said, difficult to deal with this complicated matter within the limits of a short speech, and. I would, therefore, suggest to the Government, or to any one interested in the subject, that they should look at the arguments and the calculations and the tables in the Report of the Local Taxation Commission to which I have already referred. What we all want to do is to prevent a district such as West Ham being overburdened on account of the density of the population and the comparative poverty of the inhabitants, and to take care that districts like the western isles of Scotland are not overburdened owing to the very opposite circumstances. You should see that the valuation of all districts is made upon
155 something like a comprehensive and fair scale. It is perfectly obvious that if you leave the valuation to the district itself they will lower the valuation for the purpose of showing how much higher in the pound the rate is. You can lower a. valuation to such an extent as would show that 20s. in the pound is not more in one district than 8s. or 10s. in the pound in another. So long as you have no national system of valuation you are liable to this difficulty, that you place a premium on the locality to cut down its valuation as low as it. can. No one is more aware than myself how imperfect and fragmentary the remarks are that I have made, but I am most anxious that this aspect of the question should be considered, and I have been encouraged to bring it before the notice of those interested mainly on account of the promise we have received from the Leader of the House in the course of this debate.

: My Lords, there is no member of your Lordships' House who speaks with higher authority on this question than Lord Balfour, and certainly the suggestions he has made in this debate or at any other time carry the greatest weight, and I will undertake to convey the points he has raised to-day to my right hon. friend the Chancellor of the Exchequer. I much regret the absence from the Government Bench of my noble friend Lord Fitzmaurice, whose wide experience and intimate knowledge of local government naturally entitle him also to speak with great authority, and would have enabled him to make an adequate reply to the observations of the noble Lord. All that I can attempt to do myself is to give some idea of the attitude of the Treasury in this matter, and to endeavour to reply to one or two of the criticisms that have been made against the Government.
So far as I have followed the debate, it seems to me that it has disclosed a considerable measure of agreement as between both sides of the House. We are agreed for instance, that the present system is entirely unsatisfactory; we are agreed that it stands in need of revision, and that the relations of local and Imperial taxation require re-adjustment. The present system is unsatisfactory because it is a system of doles, because it is a haphazard system, because it is inequitable, and because it does not conduce to economical adminis 156 tration. For example, I am told that a penny rate on the United Kingdom would result in about £1,000,000 being raised. But supposing that a grant of £1,000,000 was made from the Exchequer our experience goes to show that that would certainly not result in a corresponding reduction of the local rates. Then there is confusion in keeping the accounts and inequalities of rating. Rich authorities with high rateable value and high local expenditure get an undue share, which ought in justice to be given to poorer ones. Then there is municipal indebtedness, to which several noble Lords have referred. I have one or two figures to show the very high rate at which this indebtedness has increased. In 1902–3 the total amount of outstanding loans of local authorities in England and Wales, other than the Metropolitan Water Board, was £370,607,493. In 1907–8 it was £455,522,578. These, I think, are rather alarming figures, and do give cause for serious and anxious consideration.

: Might I ask the noble Lord whether the figures he has quoted appear in any Return, or whether he is doing us the service of giving us original figures which we cannot otherwise obtain? I only ask because I have not got them quite accurately down.

: I am happy to tell the noble Marquess that this Return was presented a day or two ago in another place, and, if he desires, I think it can be presented to your Lordships' House. There will be no difficulty whatever in getting it.
: I am much obliged to the noble Lord.

: The noble Earl, Lord Dunmore, in his rather interesting speech, adopted a somewhat novel way of taking the Government to task for the indebtedness of the country, because he lumped together municipal accounts and the accounts of the Imperial Exchequer and then said, "Look at what a terrible result you have arrived." But I would put it to him that we are not directly responsible for the alarming rate at which municipal debt is increasing, and I would remind him of the record of the Government with regard to the National Debt. Since
157 the Government came into office the National Debt has been reduced by some thing over £40,000,000, and there is a provision in this year's Budget for a further £9,000,000 reduction. I think that is really a. very creditable financial record for any Government to hold.
Then the noble Earl went on to attack us—it is rather a. familiar complaint—on the ground that Parliament had continued to place fresh burdens upon local authorities. I agree that Parliament has done so, hut, as my noble friend Lord Sheffield reminded the House, the Government of noble Lords opposite certainly did this to just as great an extent as, if not to a greater extent than, we have done. There was, for instance, the Education Act of 1902, which placed an enormous burden upon the rates. There was the Unemployed Workmen's Act, 1905, which also placed a very heavy burden on the rates; and it would be very easy for any one more familiar with the subject than myself to quote a number of instances Where Acts of Parliament of Conservative Governments have placed enormous burdens upon local authorities. If we have been sinners in this respect, I am bound to say that the noble Earl and his friends have been criminals of the deepest dye. Against that we may fairly also say that local authorities have frequently come to Parliament and asked for fresh powers which have considerably increased expenditure on their part.
I would like to remind the House that at present the grants given by the Treasury to local authorities are very high. In the last year for which 1 have figures available, 1908, they amount to no less than £20,630,000. I could give details of how that grant is distributed, but I do not think it is necessary at this stage of the debate. The position is not quite the same as when this subject was debated in your Lordships' House some two years ago, because since then we have passed the Old Age Pensions Act. Old people will no longer be maintained by the rates, and therefore will not be a burden upon them. In England and Wales the number of paupers fell from 229,474 on the 31st March, 1906, to 196,064 on the 1st of January of this year, which shows a decrease of over 33,000, and allowing for the increase of population, including Scotland and Ireland, the actual decrease. I should say will be well over 158 40,000, which will give a relief of over £300,000 a year to local authorities in the country.
Then there are the Land Taxes, half of which have been allocated, as noble Lords are aware, to local authorities. It is true that this year an arrangement has been come to whereby the Exchequer takes the yield of half of the Land Taxes that would have gone to local authorities and has given local authorities a sum of money slightly larger instead. It is also true that this year, and possibly for the next year or two, the yield of the Land Taxes may not be very high, but in years to come, when the increment value duty has fairly got into operation, this will yield a very considerable source of income, and I think the local authorities will enormously profit thereby.
One or two remarks have been made about the particular case of London. I could go into that in some detail, but I will spare your Lordships at this hour. I will only say that London has one-seventh of the population of England and Wales' and has one-fifth of the rateable value, so that the rateable value per head is nearly fifty per cent. higher in London than elsewhere, and there is little doubt that there is a corresponding different taxable capacity. That shows an advantage to London in this matter, if the circumstances of the particular cases of England and Wales and London were comparable, there might be some case for giving London the extra grant for which the noble Earl asked this afternoon. But I maintain that the circumstances are not at all comparable, and I do not think the Treasury would be justified in giving this concession. The fact has been ignored that the Government contribute considerable sums, as much as £10,000 to the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, £100,000 to the Metropolitan Police, and other contributions in lieu of rates in respect of Government property in London, and London has the further advantage of being the seat of Government in this country and practically the centre of the Empire, by which, I think, London indirectly benefits.
The noble Earl has a Motion on the Paper in which he moves for a Return. I am informed that it would he very difficult indeed to give the particulars he wants with regard to foreign countries. That is the information I have from the Foreign Office. Lord Belper also asks for information, but
159 as he did not put his request on the Paper, I am unable to give a definite reply. I will, how ever, refer the matter to the Foreign Office, and I will certainly undertake to obtain the information if the Foreign Office are able to give their assistance in the matter. Then the noble Earl moves for another Return giving the financial relations in British possessions. As to that I have to say that there are great difficulties in the way of giving the returns for which the noble Earl asks with regard to the Crown Colonies, but my noble friend the Secretary of State for the Colonies will communicate with the Dominion Governments and will ask them whether they are able to furnish the information desired, in which case, of course, it will be laid on the Table.
Speaking generally, I think already there has been a good deal of discussion of this question, but it has not yet reached an acute stage like some of the controversies in which we have been engaged in the past two or three years. The noble Lord, Lord Balfour, suggests that both sides should endeavour to come to some agreement in this matter. I seriously hope that they may be able to do so, but I am bound to say I do see difficulties ahead. I think it is fairly obvious that pretty well every local authority in this country—all the spending authorities: county councils, town councils, district councils, and boards of guardians—will approach the Government. with a demand or request, as the case may be, for relief. It seems to me, if I may say so, that the taxpayer is a person who is entitled to a great deal of consideration in this matter. So far as I can gather from the remarks that most noble Lords have made, they all contend that burdens should be taken off the rates and placed on the Exchequer. The noble Earl, Lord Dunmore, appeared to think that ratepayers will have no opportunity of making their voices heard in this matter. My own opinion is exactly the contrary. It seems to me that ratepayers would bring pressure to bear upon Members of the House of Commons who would naturally urge the Government to do something for particular localities all over the country. I think very often it is the case that the ratepayers feel the burdens more acutely because a great many of them pay their rates in cash, while a very considerable number of taxpayers in this country pay their taxes in indirect taxation, in commodities like tea, sugar, coffee, and similar articles. It does seem to me, 160 therefore, that when a settlement of this question is in sight the claims of the ratepayers will be urged with even greater force than those of the taxpayers.
The noble Lord, Lord Clinton, in the course of his very interesting remarks, suggested that certain charges should be transferred from local authorities to the Exchequer. I am bound to say that I think it will be necessary to approach any proposal of that kind for any sweeping transference of a charge hitherto borne by the rates to the Exchequer with the utmost caution; and I think, whilst a comprehensive survey of what are local and what are national charges must necessarily be undertaken, that above all it will be necessary for this Government or any Government that may deal with this matter to endeavour to hold even the scales as between the ratepayers and the taxpayers of this country.

: My Lords, although I do not think we shall agree with quite all that was said by the noble Lord who has just sat down, we cannot but congratulate my noble friend who opened this debate with so admirable a speech on the announcement that has been made by the Government. There is a substantial grievance, and the Government tell us that they propose to deal with the whole subject next year, and that in the interval they are willing to furnish us with all the information they can. We attach great importance to that, because I am sure it will be felt on all hands that the advantage of to-night's debate has been to show a great deal of common ground between the two sides and no sharp division of opinion as to the rival merits of the ratepayers and the taxpayers; and so far as we can get the information for which my noble friend has asked, we shall certainly be advancing towards more common ground in the consideration of the question.
I have ventured to press upon your Lordships one point which I would mention again. I do think that all parties in this country are bound to use their influence, as far as they can, to arouse those who are responsible for electing public representatives to a realisation of the enormous expenditure which they are forcing on those representatives. Whether it can be done, as Lord Balfour proposes, by bringing home to individuals that they are paying rates, or whether in so doing we shall revert to a system which
161 means an increased cost of collection, I cannot say; but I believe the noble Earl, who served longer than I did on the London County Council, will be of my opinion, that the enormous increase which goes on and which is not confined to one Government or to another is to be deprecated and that it is absolutely necessary that in agricultural districts some powers should be given, which I think are not now possessed in a good many county councils, to enable those responsible for the finance to check the otherwise perfectly legitimate demands, which conjointly mount up to so enormous a sum, by the various committees.
I have not risen to make a speech, but I do feel that the whole of this subject, just as with regard to the subject of national expenditure, is absolutely slipping out of our hands, and that economy has gone to Saturn and Jupiter, as Mr. Gladstone was accustomed to say, and I feel that local expenditure is following suit For example, may I say that three hours ago when I was sitting on the Finance Committee of the London County Council we were approached with three schemes from different committees between them amounting to a million of money. Not one of the three committees had any idea that another committee was going to raise so large a question, and not one of the three, until it was pointed out to them, seemed to think it necessary that some authority should weigh what would be the charge on the ratepayers for the next fifteen or twenty years if the adoption of all those schemes was sanctioned. They considered they were all admirable, and that each of them ought to be carried out in some form or another. I mention that because the subject is getting far beyond ordinary ken.
I want to make one reservation with regard to the speech of the noble Lord opposite. He pointed out that all Governments are guilty of throwing these charges on the ratepayers. I think there is a great deal of difference, if I may say so, between a large scheme deliberately thrown on the ratepayers with the full assent of Parliament, such, for instance, as the Education Act of 1902, and this constant frittering away of money with small Acts to which no attention is drawn. I cannot help hoping that your Lordships will set the example to the House of Commons by insisting on all Bills which do throw a charge on the ratepayers having some dis 162 tinguishing mark on that particular portion of the Bill which creates the charge. That is no unreasonable demand, and it would have very considerable effect in rousing such guardians of the local purse as my noble friend, Lord Helper, and others, and it would call your Lordships' attention to what we are engaged upon.

: My Lords, perhaps I might be allowed to express my gratitude at receiving the assurance which the noble Earl the Leader of the House was kind enough to give us in regard to the intention of the Government to deal with this question not later than next year. I trust that when His Majesty's Government do take up this matter they will very seriously consider the proposals put forward by Lord Balfour to-night, and which are contained in the Report of the Royal Commission on Local Taxation. I remember some two years ago studying his system of block grants for the relief of local expenditure, which had the merit of taking into consideration the ability of the district, to pay for the services required, and which is the only system I have ever studied which seemed to me to encourage economy in the local body and at the same time relieve districts in proportion to their ability to bear the burden. I do not wish at this period of the evening to enter into any of the rather controversial questions which Lord Denman raised, such as the reduction of the National Debt, which is largely an automatic reduction owing to the process of the Sinking Fund. In initiating the discussion this evening I pointed out that I did not wish to make a Party question of this, or to make any attack on the Government for their delay in dealing with this matter. After what the noble Lord has said I will not press my Motion. I am quite content to leave it in the hands of His Majesty's Government to give us all the information, as I am sure they will do, that is in their power.

section.title:
YEOMANRY RIFLE BUCKETS AND
AMMUNITION.
section.p: *LORD LAMINGTON rose to ask the Under-Secretary of State for War why Yeomanry regiments are not equipped with proper buckets for the new rifles, and whether the allowance of blank ammunition cannot be increased.

The noble Lord said: I rise to ask the Question that stands in my name. The matters referred to therein have, I think, been the subject of representation to the War Office, and I should like to hear what answer can be given by His Majesty's Government on the subject.

p.member: THE UNDER-SECRETARY OF STATE FOR WAR (LORD LUCAS)
p.membercontribution: : My Lords, I am afraid that the question of the ammunition, as far as I can trace it, is not one that has been referred to us. This is the first we have heard that the allowance which is given at the present time is supposed to be inadequate. Twenty-five rounds per man are issued, and an extra ten rounds when the Territorial is manœuvring with Regulars. We do not feel inclined to increase that if we can possibly help it, because it is an expense, and although it is a necessary expense it is one of those things that we like to keep down as low as we possibly can. With regard to the question of the rifle bucket, we are issuing instructions for the adaptation of the present rifle bucket to the short rifle. The bucket, of course, was designed for the long rifle, and I know there is some difficulty in carrying the short rifle with it; but if certain alterations are made, if the straps are shortened, we do not think that there will be any particular difficulty in carrying the rifle in the same way as the long rifle was carried. We are not disposed at the present time to consider providing the other bucket which has been asked for—namely, the 164 bucket which the Cavalry have—because, among other things, we do attach great importance to the Yeoman and his rifle being attached to each other, so that if he gets separated from his horse he will always have his rifle.

: I am not officially informed, but I understand that there was a representation from Scotland as regards the insufficiency of the blank ammunition. It is a serious deficiency. You cannot with twenty-five rounds carry out all the field days, five or six in the course of training, and consequently these field days will lose half their value. It is impossible to understand how operations are to be conducted without having at least thirty or forty rounds per man, and I certainly understood that a. representation was made from Scotland last year for a grant of 200 rounds a year per man. That, I know, is considered by various commanding officers as the absolute minimum, and I know of one commanding office: who had to buy ammunition for one squadron of his regiment, this training or last training, to supply this want. With regard to the rifle buckets, if the Cavalry find it necessary to have these buckets it seems only reasonable to suppose that the Yeomanry also require them. I am glad to hear that some attempt is being made to improve matters, but certainly the present bucket is bad both for the horseman and rifle. If the present bucket can be adapted, well and good, but, if not, undoubtedly in the interests of all there should be a new bucket supplied. I also hope that the noble Lord will consider having a larger amount of blank ammunition. I am sure other representations will be made on the matter.

section.title:
EDUCATION (PHYSICAL TRAINING)
BILL. [H.L.]
section.p: [SECOND READING.]
Order of the Day for the Second Reading read.

p.membercontribution:
: My Lords, the Bill which stands in my name, and to which I am asking your Lordships to give a Second Reading this afternoon, is one which I think will commend itself to your Lordships. It is a non-contentious Bill, and I am thankful to say it is a non-Party Bill. As is set out in the Memorandum attached to the Bill, its object is to secure continuous physical training for the youth of both sexes up to the age of sixteen years, in order, as far as possible, to ensure for each young person the possession of sound and healthy vital organs, a. deep mobile chest, and the development of an evenly-balanced muscular and nervous system, and thus to arrest the deplorable physical degeneration disclosed by the Report of the Inter-Departmental Committee on Physical Deterioration.
Before I attempt to touch upon any of the clauses, I should like to make a few
167 remarks upon the general question. Physical training is no new idea, nor is it promoted by faddists, as some people imagine. It is backed by the whole of the medical profession throughout the civilised world. Sweden has had physical training for over a century, and we in England have to a certain extent introduced it in our Army and Navy and in our colleges in recent years, and two years. ago I congratulated His Majesty's Government upon introducing it into the education curriculum of our elementary and secondary schools. The only objection to the Government's scheme, to my mind, was that it did not go far enough. It only takes the education of our children up to the age of fourteen, at which age they leave school. The Bill that I am asking your Lordships to read a second time this afternoon takes children up to the age of sixteen, and I think we are all agreed that the ages between fourteen and sixteen, and even up to eighteen, constitute the most critical time in a child's life as far as his health and physical culture are concerned.
I have for many years taken a great interest in the health of the children of the masses of this country, and I have personally studied the various systems of physical training throughout the world; and having carefully studied the subject, when this Bill was shown to me last year by the promoters—the National Hygienic League —I had no hesitation in informing them that it would give me great pleasure to introduce it in your Lordships' House. The information which I have acquired from personal experience of physical training shows that the children as a whole are not gaining or improving under the present system. The chief reason that I could find for that is that the teachers themselves do not possess that practical knowledge which they should have in order to impart this instruction to their pupils. For that reason the physical culture as it is at present given in our schools is practically useless as far as the health and future physique of the children are concerned. The object of this Bill is not to produce athletes or acrobats. That is not our object. Our object is to ensure for each young person good physical health in the future; and in order to do that it is absolutely necessary that the teachers themselves should have practical experience and knowledge of this physical training before they impart it to the children.
168 I have quite recently been inspecting several of our schools throughout the country where this so-called physical culture is given under the Board of Education. What do I find? It is given in a very mechanical way. The teachers have a book laying down what they are to do, which way a child's arms are to be held, and how a child is to stand, and that is about all they know. They say it by heart, and that satisfies the inspectors. But that is practically no good for the child's health or his future physical culture. Ninety-five per cent. of the children would not be able to say why they were doing this drill, or what good it was going to do them in the future. That is exactly how physical culture is being taught in our schools at the present time. What I want to bring about by this Bill is an improvement in the physique and the health of the children of this country, and in order to do that we must have the teachers instructed upon a sound basis. The system which we propose in this Bill is based on the fact that time teachers should have an accurate theoretical and practical knowledge of the physiological effect of each exercise, which effect is pre-determined and specially localised. If we do this, the children will receive benefit from it.
The physical welfare of the boys and girls of this country should be the first consideration, not only of the State, but of time whole Empire, and it must be very noticeable to any one who is constantly going through our large towns and cities that, almost every minute of the day you see children of all sizes and all grades with humped backs and congested and flat chests, half of them walking about with their mouths wide open—a regular death trap, for they inhale every microbe. That alone should help to convince us of the necessity of devising some machinery by which our children can obtain proper physical exercise and be taught how to carry themselves in their every-day life. We know that the youths of this country have greatly deteriorated. In the time of Cromwell our race was known as the finest in the world, but I doubt very much if we can make that statement to-day. The average height of the Englishman to-day is about 5ft. 7in., and that of an Englishwoman 5ft. 5in., and I am given to understand by those who have obtained information on the point that in America and
169 Sweden the average is 1½in. higher. We know that in recruiting for the British Army we have found great difficulty in obtaining men of the proper standard. I have figures here which show that out of 77,000 youths who offered themselves for enlistment over 29,000 were rejected as physically unfit. I claim that that would not have been the case if we had had a system of physical training in force such as is suggested in this Bill. And we remember what a great difficulty there was in the late South African war in finding men of physique and stamina to go to the Front.
It is true that there are many gymnasia scattered all over the country, and in most schools physical training in some form or other is being taught; but in these cases how many of the children know what they are being taught this drill for? I regret to say that in many instances the teachers use these drills as a punishment for the children whom they are unable to manage in the classes. The consequence is that the child hates the drill and it is most distasteful to him. Under the provisions of this Bill I hope to make physical training a pleasure to the child. Violent exercises are not necessary. What is needed is careful instruction as to the child's proper way of standing and above all the proper way of breathing, which is really the base of the whole matter. If our children were taught how to breathe properly and how to stand, we should overcome a great many of the difficulties which we now experience. These flat-chested children in time develop lung and other diseases, but by a proper system of breathing and by physical exercises such as we propose in this Bill they would to a certain extent be able to fight against them.
As I have said, ninety-five per cent. of the children in the schools to-day are quite unaware of the benefit receivable from physical culture; but if the children were properly taught I have not the slightest doubt that we should be able to bring the standard of our future generations up to what it ought to be. In order that we may have this physical training properly given, it will be necessary to set up some machinery by which either the present teachers in the schools may be so instructed that they will be able to impart the knowledge in a proper and efficient way to the children, or special teachers will have to be appointed to visit certain districts. This need not be a drill 170 which will be distasteful to the children. After they have been properly instructed as to the benefit they are to receive, they will take a pleasure in their drill, and there will be no occasion to use the compulsory clauses of which we have a few in the: Bill.
I have no doubt that many of your Lordships have read the Report of Lord George Hamilton's Commission on the Poor Law, in an Appendix to which Mr. Sidney Jackson alludes to physical training and shows very clearly the great necessity there is for it in this country. Sweden introduced physical training in the year 1839, and to-day it forms part and parcel of their every-day life. Every man, woman, boy, and girl is doing physical training constantly in Sweden, with the result that they have good physique and are in a healthy condition; and in that country we do not see about the streets those poked heads, narrow chests, and humped backs which are so common in this country. In America of recent years they have also brought physical training greatly into effect. What can be done in other countries surely we can do in England.
No doubt I shall be told by noble Lords opposite that one of the great difficulties is the expense. I do not intend to go into the financial side of the question, but I should like to say that already there is a large expenditure upon the physical training at present carried out in our schools, and I am told by experts that the extra physical training which I am asking for in this Bill will not be of such great cost that it need be specially mentioned in a Second Reading debate. From what I can understand, there is a very good scheme prepared by the National Hygienic League, which if taken into consideration by His Majesty's Government, would enable this Bill to be put into operation very easily. There are several clauses in the Bill which I fully expect will be criticised. I hope that the criticisms will be many, because it will enable us to put the Bill into better shape. I think I can assume that the principle of the Bill will be accepted by all your Lordships, but no doubt the machinery which has been devised to carry it out may receive rather severe criticism. I have heard that there are to be some criticisms upon certain clauses, but not knowing what those criticisms will be I cannot anticipate them.
I believe there are some difficulties with regard to making arrangements with the
171 Board of Education for carrying out the training of the teachers. Probably that will be one criticism. There will be another criticism upon the continuation of these classes after the child has left school, but I do not see any reason why there should be. We already have evening classes, at which the attendance is very good. The boys are being taught trades of all kinds, and the girls domestic economy. I think if we were to add a good physical training we should then have some of the most perfect schools in the world. If a child attended these physical drills twice or three times a week, it would be sufficient, once he understood what he was to do and what benefit he was to receive by it, to enable him to carry on the physical culture himself in his own home. I am perfectly certain that it would be done with the greatest pleasure by all children, and that there would be no difficulty as far as that is concerned. Neither would there be any objections raised by parents, for since this Bill has been in circulation I have received communications from all parts of England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, not from teachers and experts, but from parents themselves, welcoming the Bill and expressing the hope that it will become law. I do not think I need go into particulars of the clauses, because I should like to hear the criticisms of those who will speak after me. But before sitting down I would say that the criticisms might be met to a certain extent by our meeting together and consulting on the matter, and probably if the Bill reaches another stage they could be met by the insertion of Amendments. I commend the Bill to your Lordships, and I trust that it will meet with a favourable reception at your hands and at the hands of His Majesty's Government, and that we shall in the near future see it passed into law. I beg to move.
Moved, That the Bill be now read 2a.— (Viscount Hill.)

: My Lords, I am sure we have all listened with sympathy to the words that have fallen from the noble Viscount. At the same time the noble Viscount seems to be in ignorance of the fact that physical exercises have been carried out in the schools of this country for a great deal longer than two years. It is now twenty-one years since I myself introduced a Bill into this House. I re-introduced the Bill twenty years ago. It was rejected at the time, as most novel 172 measures are in Parliament, but the third year it was introduced it was accepted practically en bloc by the Liberal Government of the day. I went to the Minister who was responsible for education at the time, and who had just come into office, and asked him if he was going to oppose my proposal like his predecessor had done. He said, "No, I do not think there is any reason for it. I think I can incorporate your Bill in my Code." That was done; and ever since those days physical exercises have been carried on in the schools of this country.
I cannot say that I agree with all the noble Viscount has said about the small effect which those physical exercises have had upon the children. I am not here to defend His Majesty's Government. They are perfectly capable of defending themselves, and we shall hear what their spokesman has to say later. But my experience, and it is a large experience, is not that of the noble Viscount. I am continually going round visiting schools, not only in my neighbourhood but in others, in connection with another matter, and I have never yet found a school where there is no actual practical drill. I have found that as a general rule really excellent work is being done. I do not think the noble Viscount is aware—at all events he has not mentioned it—that these physical exercises are done under regulation and organisation. After the Government of the day accepted the Bill which I brought in and included it in their Code, a Committee, on which I had the honour of sitting, was appointed by the War Office and the Education Department, and a gentleman named Colonel Fox was put at the head of it. A syllabus was drawn up. That syllabus has, no doubt, been altered since those days, and what I thought was a very useful part of it—the military part—has been to a large extent eliminated. But at all events the syllabus is there. I hold in my hand the last syllabus of physical exercises for public elementary schools issued by the Board of Education in l909, and if the noble Viscount reads that syllabus lie will see that Sir Robert Morant and those who work with him have gone very thoroughly into the question. They have considered very carefully all that is absolutely necessary for the health of the children, and although there are parts of the syllabus with which I do not agree—especially, as I have said, the one
173 from which military drill has been eliminated—still I must say I think that, as far as it goes, it is an excellent system.
I would also point out to the noble Viscount that this system has been founded in a great measure upon the very one which he has been pressing—the Swedish system. I know that that system was introduced, because I was chairman of a voluntary association which gave £400 to bring over from Sweden one of the first teachers who gave instruction to the teachers in London in the Swedish system. No doubt there have been alterations from the actual pure Swedish system, but I do not think there are any alterations with which the noble Viscount or any one else can find fault. Therefore I am glad to be able to say that I do not agree with the noble Viscount in his statement that the exercises, as far as they have gone, have not been of use. I have judged on four different occasions the exercises of the children attending the London elementary schools, and I can tell the noble Viscount that if he would go to one of those exhibitions and see the exercises performed he would be more than pleased. It is wonderful what the children do, and their work is a source of great delight and pleasure to any one who feels, as we all do, that this matter is one of very great importance to the nation at large. The noble Viscount speaks about acrobats. I have never seen any acrobatic performances of any kind or description in connection with elementary schools. The performances that I have seen are almost entirely Swedish—pthat is to say, without apparatus. Of course, it is absolutely wrong that this drill should be given as a punishment, but I have never known it so given. If it is done, I should hope that after the debate to-night such a thing will be stopped. As a matter of fact, the drills that I have seen are enjoyed by the children. I do not know whether, if you were to ask every child whether he is aware of the purport of the drill, he would be able to give you an answer, but I do not think it very much matters whether he knows what the drill is for or not, as long as the drill is improving his physical condition.
I regret very much that the noble Viscount has put into his Bill a clause directly eliminating military drill. I think that is a most fatal thing for the Legislature of this country to do. The trend of 174 public opinion, whatever some of us may think, is in the direction of military drill for the young. Our Colonies are showing us the way to do it, and we shall have to come to it some day whether we like it or not; and it appears to me a fatal and retrograde measure to put a clause into a Bill saying that under no circumstances whatever shall military drill be carried out in the schools of this country. I hope that that clause, at all events, will be deleted. I do not suppose for one moment that the noble Viscount really desires the elimination of military drill. We know there are people in this country who believe that military drill is very wicked. How they can arrive at that conclusion I, for one, am absolutely at a loss to understand. But I suppose the noble Viscount thought it was wise and expedient to put in such a clause in order that the Bill might pass.
Personally, I do not see any necessity for the Bill except in regard to the raising of the age, and in that I entirely agree with the noble Viscount. At present we only have physical exercises up to the age of 14, and I, for one, should be delighted to support any Bill which would make it compulsory upon every child to go through physical exercises up to the age of sixteen, and I would even say longer. In Sweden the age is eighteen, and no difficulty has been found with regard to it there. I would also give one warning to the noble Viscount. I have had a good deal of experience in regard to physical exercises. I have been myself at the head of one of the teachers' associations for physical exercises. The noble Viscount must remember that there are a great number of systems of physical exercises in this country. They all want to have the knife in each other, and he must be very careful that he does not run a Bill for the express purpose of one particular class of teacher. We have to keep quite clear of that in a national work. In conclusion, I repeat that, while sympathising with the noble Viscount in the general purport of his Bill, I must say that in the particular subjects to which I have alluded I entirely disagree with him.

: My Lords, with the objects of the Bill as set forth in the Memorandum on the first page I am in entire sympathy. I cannot say that I entirely approve of the methods which it is proposed to adopt, but I shall confine my criticism to one single point. The Bill contains a most extraordinary pro-
175 vision, a provision so extraordinary, and, as it seems to me, so uncalled-for, that it has given rise to a suspicion that the objects of the promoters as set forth in the Memorandum are not their whole objects and that they have some ulterior object. The provision I refer to is that contained in Clause 4, subsection (2), which runs— "Provided always that no child or young person shall, in the course of any physical training by this Act provided, be allowed to use, or be taught the use of, any war weapon of any kind whatsoever." Why has this provision been inserted? With what object? At whose instigation? The noble Viscount was silent on the matter; but from what I know of him myself I find it very difficult to believe that he can be in sympathy with it. On the contrary, I should be very much surprised if he were not glad to see it eliminated.
This provision is directly contrary to the recommendations of the Inter-Departmental Committee, upon which the Bill professes to be based. I imagine that this provision has been put in to appease those who are known as Little Englanders. But why should we seek to appease them? Why should the noble Viscount pander to these people, with whom I know he has no sympathy whatever? It is difficult to understand the attitude of those who object to the principle of universal military service, but it is impossible to understand the attitude of mind of those who would hinder and discourage that voluntary system of military service on which we depend at the present time. Surely there is some strange inconsistency about those who object to compulsion on principle, and yet who would apply this very principle of compulsion in this drastic form for the purpose of giving physical training. I say if you are going to extend the principle of compulsion which forms part of all our legislation, and more particularly of all the laws which have to do with education and the training of the young, then why should not the State get all the advantage it possibly can from that compulsion? Why should the State impose on itself this restriction which is contained in the particular section of the Bill which I have read? Why should it fetter the discretion of the local authorities? What becomes of those principles of local self-government and trust in the people with which we are all so ready to profess our sympathy and our belief?
176 I take it that no one will disagree that the first necessity of the State, indeed of any State, is that of self-protection, of defence, and I think it is also pretty clear that if you have healthy and vigorous citizens they are better capable of taking part in the defence of the State than those who are weak and degenerate and of the description to which the noble Viscount referred. But if that be so, why should the State pay for this additional physical training and then deliberately and of its own will forego the greatest advantage which might result from it? I go a step further. Why should you deprive your physical training of that one element which would be more likely than any other to make it effective? We all know that brain and muscle depend and interact on one another. Very little advantage can be derived from muscular exercises unless there is sonic mental stimulus. We all know that an interesting and exciting game does a great deal more good than mere exercises with dumbbells or Indian clubs. If you want the whole population to improve their physique and to do so with heartiness and goodwill—and that was one of the points on which the noble Viscount particularly dwelt, and I may say that it impressed me that he felt undue confidence in his system in that very respect—you must give them some motive which appeals to the imagination, and it must be a motive which affects the nation as a whole.
The noble Viscount told us that most of the children who go through the present-day physical exercises do not know what the drill is for, and he was eager to admit that this was a disadvantage and marred the value of those very physical exercises. Surely that is a point to which lie ought to have given attention. He ought to have supplied this mental stimulus. He ought to have provided a motive which appeals to the nation as a whole. What higher and better motive is there than that of patriotism? If you make the object of your physical exercises one which has direct reference to patriotism, you will give that stimulus, and one which will be understood by all, even by the youngest child; and I defy any one to name any other motive which could take the place of such a one. And in this respect I should like to ask, Why are the patriotic to pay for their own physical training when it is a matter of Cadet Corps, Church Lads
177 Brigade, and so forth, while the unpatriotic are to get it at the public expense? That seems to me to be an inconsistency which requires some explanation.
We all want to improve the physique of the nation—I take it we are all thoroughly alive to the unsatisfactory condition of the national physique at the present time—and I do not hesitate to say that I am one of those who believe firmly that the proper method of doing so is that of universal military service. That is a method which is known to be successful. We have the example of other countries. We have the example of our own country in the past. The noble Viscount himself admitted it. He told us that in the days of Cromwell the physique of our nation was better than that of any other. But to those who do not care for the teachings of history, or for the example of foreign nations, I would point to the great success which attends military form of exercises at the present time. By what method can you do more good to poor, weedy lads from the slums of great cities than by giving them a spell of military training in a seaside camp or elsewhere, and by giving them some of the advantages which the rich obtain anyhow, and which are out of the reach of the poor? With those examples before us, why should we go and deliberately say that the military method of physical training is to be barred?
You object to militarism, whatever militarism might mean. You are not going to check militarism by keeping the people ignorant of the use of the weapons of war. If you want to check militarism you must keep soldiers out of their sight. You must never let them see a soldier or heat anything about the Army. But if you think that there is so much latent and potential military ardour in the nation that the mere fact that they are taught to shoot with the rifle will make them all burn with a desire to go into the Army, how can you consistently say that the nation as a whole will never accept universal military service? Again, you profess to be democratic, and I presume it is considered to be democratic to give in a measure of this kind to the poor advantages at the public expense which are at present only within the reach of the well-to-do. If that be your principle, why withhold from them the healthy and admittedly beneficial exercise of practice with military 178 arms and particularly of rifle shooting? I said at the outset that I was going to confine my criticism to this one point, and I will do so. I feel very strongly upon it, and if the Bill gets to a further stage I shall certainly ask your Lordships to omit subsection (2) of Clause 4.

: My Lords, with the view of the noble Lord who has just sat down I entirely concur. I should be exceedingly glad to see a measure for universal military training passed into law. The provision which the noble Viscount has inserted in the Bill apparently in order to make it easier to pass has been used as an argument against the whole Bill. But whatever may be said with regard to the earlier part of the Bill, there is one clause in it—I refer to Clause 5—which makes me hope that your Lordships will give the Bill a Second Reading. It is in entire accord with the recommendations of the important Commission which sat upon the relief of distress that something should be done to keep a hold upon those boys who leave school at the age of fourteen, and Clause 5 constitutes a great step forward in dealing with those who form the large class of "unemployables." I hope your Lordships will give the Bill a Second Reading, although I trust that in Committee the clause which has been so severely criticised by the noble Lord who has just sat down will be deleted.

p.member: THE LORD PRESIDENT OF THE COUNCIL (EARL BEAUCHAMP)
p.membercontribution:
: My Lords, I should like to associate myself with the expressions of general approval of the principle which underlies this Bill, and the desire that there should be a complete system of physical training in this country. But having expressed so much approval of the principle of the Bill, the noble Viscount probably knows enough about the general practice in debates in this House to expect that I shall now venture to explain to him various reasons why the Bill as it stands is not acceptable to His Majesty's Government. It was with regret that I heard the noble Viscount express disapproval of the present physical education which is given in the schools of this country. 1 would venture to ask him, however, in what way this Bill will improve that physical education. It leaves it in the hands of the same authorities as have the control of it at the present time, and I think it will be necessary for him to
179 include in his Bill sonic assured method of getting the physical education more in accordance with what he wishes it to be.
I think it only fair to point out, on behalf of the Board of Education, that the work of physical training in the schools has lately been reorganised. It is only since January that the work has been so reorganised, and I am sure the noble Viscount would be one of the first to acknowledge that work of this kind cannot be remedied all at once. The thing is to train the teachers, and I can assure him that that work is already in hand. It was only last night that the President of the Board of Education made a general statement upon the work of his Department, and I shall venture to quote to your Lordships the passages which especially refer to physical education. My right hon. friend said— "On another side of their physical condition I have to report that great developments have taken place in the matter of physical exercises. Two years ago some members of my Board embarked on devising a general physical exercise syllabus, largely on the Swedish system. That syllabus has met with great acceptance, and 92,000 copies of it have been sold. It would be impossible to carry on the physical exercise work in all the schools under the local education authorities unless the teachers were prepared to play a part in it, and in the training colleges no fewer than 4,700 students have passed the examination in physical exercise since Christmas of last year. That means that;those teachers who go up from the training colleges will not be specialised physical exercise teachers, but it will be part of their ordinary work." My right hon. friend went on to make a reference to military service which I am afraid will not commend itself to noble Lords who have taken part in this discussion. Speaking of the difference between military service and physical training and emphasising the advantage that is given to children especially from physical training, he said— "Military service can only benefit selected men—"
: We are dealing with children, not with men.

: That is true; but I do not think there is any harm in quoting a passage from a general statement made by my right hon. friend comparing generally physical training and military service. Mr. Runciman said— "Military service can only benefit selected men. Those who are least physically fit, those who most require physical exercises, would be debarred from 180 the very training and opportunity that would be provided under a military system, and, moreover, military service does not include women and girls, and can be in no way a substitute for physical exercise. And it can only include those who are comparatively grown-up. What we want to-day is to get hold of the children as early as possible and enable them not only to develop their muscles when grown-up, but to grow up well." I think every member of your Lordships' House will agree that whatever we may think as to the benefits of military training, it ought to be preceded by some system of physical training.
Perhaps I might now turn to some of the criticisms that were offered by Lord Ampthill. I should like, in the first place, to offer one humble word of defence for the clause which he so much dislikes—the clause which prohibits the use of war weapons. I believe it is so at the present time that recruits before joining the Army are generally trained by a system of Swedish drill. They are not trained, that is to say, with the help of war weapons; and I would venture to ask noble Lords who wish war weapons to be used in this way, what kind of war weapon they would wish in order to assist physical training? In order to develop the muscles generally there is no weapon of war in general use which can effectively be used with a system of Swedish drill. Scientific physical training is far more likely to develop the muscles and physique of children than any exercises with rifles or even with larger implements of war. I might even quote the noble Lord (Lord Ampthill) himself as an example. We are apt, I think, many of us to point to the noble Lord as perhaps the most. splendid specimen of physique in this House. May I put it to him that that splendid result was not attained by the use of the rifle, but more, I think, by the oar, with which he obtained so many successes at Henley in years gone by. I think, in these circumstances, it is not unfair to say that the use of. weapons of war is probably not the best method of obtaining a good physical result.
I now turn to one or two of the detailed criticisms upon some of the clauses of the Bill. The curriculum of the elementary school is already so full that we should very strongly object to that clause in the Bill which requires that as much as two hours a week should be devoted to this system of physical training. I think it is only fair to say, too, that that period which is devoted
181 to what is definitely called physical training at the present time does not comprehend he whole of the time which is spent in improving the physique of the children. In their play very often, also in the way in which they are made to stand and breathe while reading, and in matters of that kind, a great deal is done by the teachers to improve the physique of the children. although it is not given under the heading of physical training. Then I come to the examining Board. I think that that could hardly be undertaken by the Board of Education except at considerable expense. That is a subject to which I shall refer in a moment, but one which, after the debate we had yesterday in this House, I think ought to attract special attention from noble Lords, especially-in view of the somewhat airy way in which it was dealt with by the noble Viscount. We do not feel, either, that there is any need to create a special ad hoc committee for physical training under each local education authority in the way the noble Viscount suggests. There would not be very much work for such a committee to do, and we should very much object to an officer of the authority being an ex-officio member of such a committee. It would be much more to the point and bring a better result about if the larger local education authorities were to appoint paid organisers for the teaching of physical training within their area.
The other clause to which I think strong objection would be taken throughout the country is Clause 5, which certainly at the present time I do not think the country would adopt. By that clause all young people until they reach the age of sixteen years are to attend continuation schools for physical training at least two evenings in the week. Just think for one moment what the expense would be of bringing that about. You would have to hire rooms, you would require teachers, you would have to have lighting, you would require inspectors, and in an infinity of ways very large further expense would be thrown on the rates. The improvement which has taken place, or is, we hope, going to take place rapidly in the near future, in physical exercises will, we trust, go a very long way towards meeting what is the real object of this Bill. The Board hope to make examination in physical training compulsory upon all non-collegiate students.
The special question of expense, I think, bears not only with regard to these young 182 persons up to the age of sixteen, but also upon the further matter of the examination' of the various teachers. The Board, by the Bill of the noble Viscount, is expected to undertake the examination in physical training of the students in training colleges and also of non-collegiate students. In addition to that, of course, there are all the teachers who are now working in the schools. Of those there are 135,000, in addition to whom there are a large number of supplementary and unqualified teachers. Therefore it is not unreasonable to say that the Board would have to make arrangements for the examination in this matter of 150,000 teachers. I do not pretend that all those would wish or be able to undertake the work of physical training, but no doubt a large number of them would wish to get the additional qualification, and also the additional salary, which would be a further charge on the rates, and which is suggested by the noble Viscount in Clause 2, subsection (4). The general examination suggested by this Bill in order to be effective would naturally have to be somewhat thorough. An examination in practice could not take much less than ten minutes in connection with each individual, and with such a large number as the noble Viscount contemplates would pass through this examination, not only in point of time but also of numbers considerable expense must be incurred.
I have stated the objections to the Bill in its present form. It is impossible for me to advise your Lordships to give it a Second Reading on this occasion. I think what I have been able to say to the noble Viscount and what has been said by the noble Earl on the Cross Benches (Lord Meath) proves sufficiently that the Board of Education are fully alive to the importance of this matter. They have taken a new start, and have already organised a much better system of physical training; and I venture to hope and to think that if the noble Viscount will suspend his judgment until there has been time to see the result of the very important new steps and new departures which have been taken by the Board, your Lordships will on a future occasion be better able and better qualified to deal with the subject.

: My Lords, every one who listened to the speech of the noble Viscount behind me must have realised that his heart is in his
183 work, and that he desires to arrest the deplorable physical degeneration disclosed by the Report of the Inter-Departmental Committee. With the object which my noble friend has in view I feel sure every one in your Lordships' House will agree. Speaking as one who has been at the head of the Board of Education, I do not hesitate to say that I view a great deal that is in this Bill with hearty sympathy. The noble Viscount expressed the hope that the Bill would be considered non-controversial and non-political. It is in that sense that I propose to deal with it in the few remarks that I shall make to-night. And the noble Viscount also invited criticisms in order that by that means he might realise the shortcomings in his Bill, and he enabled, by amending the Bill, to carry through some of its principles with which we all agree.
At the root of the whole matter is the question how far we can improve the present system of what used to be called when I was at the Board of Education physical exercises, but now termed physical training. My noble friend seems to think that if we could have a perfect system of physical training we might be able to improve the physique of those unfortunate children who abound in our great cities, and restore them to that state of vigour which we should all like to see. But I am afraid a good deal more than physical exercises would be required to bring about this happy state of affairs. I think the children to whom the noble Viscount alluded undoubtedly owe their unhealthy condition to other circumstances than the absence of physical exercises. They owe their condition perhaps to overcrowding, perhaps to want of proper nourishment, and perhaps also to the fact that the ordinary laws of health are not properly observed by their parents.
